ygData.subject: Re: Cellular Encoding
ygData.msgSnippet: I should add that as far is direct vs. indirect, I would go with indirect on very complex problems, but CE is probably not the best indirect encoding today.

I should add that as far is direct vs. indirect, I would go with 
indirect =
on very complex problems, but CE is probably not the best 
indirect encodin=
g today.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...=
> wrote:
>
> Rafael, our 2002 paper on NEAT does include a comparison with =

> Cellular Encoding (CE):
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:ec0=
2
> 
> Our 2003 "Taxonomy for Artificial Embryogeny" paper on indirect 
> e=
ncodings also includes a fairly detailed description of CE and 
also 
> men=
tions "Edge Encoding," which was proposed to fix some of the 
> problems wi=
th CE.
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:alife03
> 
> CE was an =
early development encoding and therefore inspired a lot 
of 
> interest in =
the 90s.  It also was the first learning algorithm of 
any 
> type that I k=
now of to solve double pole balancing without velocity 
> inputs.  Another =
thing that was interesting was that Gruau proved 
in 
> his thesis that the=
 encoding can produce any graph structure, so it 
> is complete.
> 
> Howev=
er, compared to more modern approaches I do not think it is a 
> good choic=
e today.  I think the focus was too much on completeness 
> and too little =
on efficiency.  Being complete is not a great 
> advantage if it takes too =
long to find the solution.  In fact, the 
> more important issue is *bias*,=
 i.e. to what kinds of structures is 
> any particular indirect encoding bi=
ased.  CE seems biased towards 
> rigid iterative repreating structures, in=
cluding hierarchies.  For 
> example, it can solve parity problems of arbit=
rary arity.  That can 
> be impressive, but I don't believe partity problem=
s are 
> representative of most interesting problems.  CE also seems slow i=
n 
> terms of # of evaluation to a solution from the reported results.  
> =

> All indirect encodings including CPPNs have some kind of bias 
towards 
=
> producing certain kinds of structures.  Usually this bias is good 
> fora=
 certain level fo complexity.  However, at low complexity, you 
> may just =
want a direct encoding like regular NEAT.  For example, in 
> pole balancin=
g, there is no need for indirect encoding because the 
> problem is small, =
so NEAT will be much faster than CE.
> 
> Overall, CE is not in use very mu=
ch today as far as I know and is 
> mainly a historical achievement that in=
spired further work in 
> indirect 
> encoding.
> 
> ken
